awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Dimensions: The evolution of novel interactions within a network of plant, insect and microbial biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
All species on earth interact with other species in complicated networks that include plants, animals, and microbes. These interaction networks have long fascinated biologists, who are interested in why some species depend on each other and in how these relationships matter for maintenance of biodiversity. For example, why do most insects that eat plants consume only a few types of plants in any one location? And, how did it happen that many of these insects depend on beneficial microbes (fungi and bacteria) that are found nowhere else except with those insects. This project will explore how such specialized interactions arise.  Specifically, researchers will investigate the evolution of new interactions among insects, microbes, and an economically important plant (alfalfa) in western North America.  By identifying the key factors that underlie the insect-microbe-plant interactions in this study system, the research will fill a substantial gap in our understanding of the diversity of life, and enhance our ability to predict how global change will affect biological diversity and ecosystem function. The researchers will also engage and collaborate with the public through a discovery-based citizen science program, and will develop new analytical tools to benefit other scientists who are interested in how species come to depend on each another.

This project examines a complex network of interacting biodiversity, including macroscopic and microscopic organisms, to answer a fundamental question: What role does biodiversity play in the evolution and maintenance of novel interactions? The research team takes advantage of a well-studied plant-insect-microbe system to investigate the importance of multiple layers of inter- and intra-specific diversity for predicting the evolution of novel interactions, specifically the colonization of alfalfa by the Melissa blue butterfly and microbes. The project combines a systems approach to biological complexity with manipulations that allow the researchers to integrate three focal dimensions of biodiversity: (1) functional diversity, encompassing how variation in phytochemistry, larval performance, and butterfly egg-laying preference are shaped by microbial, fungal, plant and caterpillar interactions; (2) genetic diversity, including the role of genomic variation within and among populations of interacting plants and insects, both in the wild and in an experiment context; and (3) phylogenetic diversity, focusing on gut bacteria in insects, as well as fungal and bacterial endophytes in plants.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we examined a complex network of interacting biodiversity, including insects, plants and microscopic organisms, to answer a fundamental question: What role does biodiversity play in the evolution and maintenance of novel interactions? Our specific focus was on the importance of diversity within and among species for predicting the evolution of novel interactions, specifically the colonization of alfalfa by the Melissa blue butterfly and microbes. 

Using experimental alfalfa common gardens and genome sequencing, we demonstrated that genetic differences among alfalfa plants and Melissa blue butterflies affect whether the caterpillars grow and survive on the plants. In particular, we found that these genetic differences  accounted for nearly half of the variability in caterpillar growth and survival. Our results showed individual variation matters, and that the outcome of this plant-insect interaction is affected by many genes with mostly independent — or additive — effects. Interestingly, genetic differences among alfalfa plants have consistent effects on caterpillar growth in multiple butterfly populations and species, making such effects predictable. Beyond issues specific to insects and their host plants, genetic variation within species could also be important for other host-parasite interactions, including susceptibility to parasitic diseases in humans and other animals being a function of both genetic variation in hosts and among pathogen strains. 

These results suggest that variation among alfalfa plants might determine whether Melissa blue butterflies successfully colonize and persist on patches of alfalfa in nature. We tested this by collecting data on Melissa blue butterfly presence/absence, plant traits and plant chemistry, arthropod communities, microbial communities, soil conditions and climate at 56 alfalfa sites across the western USA. We found that the presence of L. melissa could be reliably predicted by effects of plant traits and interactions with other species. Interestingly, the single biggest factor was the presence versus absence of ants, which have a mutualistic interaction with Melissa blue caterpillars, thereby reducing attacks by predators. Thus, these results suggest that the evolution and persistence of the Melissa blue butterfly-alfalfa interaction is a consequence of many factors, including interactions with other arthropods, rather than only being driven by simple trade-offs in developmental physiology such as those captured in our common garden experiments. 

The characterization of the microbial communities present on the surface and within alfalfa tissue, as well as the microbial reservoirs in their surrounding soil provide fertile ground for generating hypotheses connecting plant genotype, phytochemistry, and arthropod communities. To serve as a resource to test hypotheses generated by these analyses, we simultaneously worked to create a collection of bacterial and fungal isolates. During the period of this grant, we characterized ~50 strains for their ability to promote plant growth via auxin production and nutrient uptake, by mobilizing nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and iron. Nutrient uptake by plants, particularly in unmanaged land, facilitated by microbes is necessary for plants to maintain their ability to produce the phytochemicals that allow them to manage interactions with herbivores. To test bacterial factors that connect microbes with our diverse phenotypes, we created a novel genetically tractable system in Pantoea sp. R4, which we have been able to make targeted mutations. Together, our characterized culture collection can be used for a multitude of future experiments.

Investigation of geographic patterns of Melissa blue butterfly and Alfalfa genomic variation provide a foundation for testing predictions derived from the common garden experiments and field data on how genetic variation shapes host-parasite interactions. These data also provide a framework for examining how ecological interactions in microbial and arthropod communities are structured.

This project resulted in beneficial broader impacts beyond the basic science conducted. Key broader impacts involved enhanced educational opportunities for students and the public. For example, the project established an alfalfa Science Garden that is now used by ~1000 undergraduate students a year to test hypotheses about the causes and consequences of plant genetic and trait variation. A related citizen science project was established to engage the broader community with documenting biological diversity (mostly insects) on alfalfa. This project also generated new computer programs useful for many scientists in analyzing genetic data from non-model species. Lastly, the project provided technical training for numerous undergraduate and graduate students who will go on to contribute in various ways to society
